title: Update to
text: initial report introduced helios: individual-based modelling framework exploring impact installation far UVC transmission burden respiratory infections. report describes updates made modelling framework since initial report (Section 1). Additionally, present series analyses evaluating impact installation far UVC non-household settings burden endemic respiratory pathogens, using “influenza-like” “SARS-CoV-2-like” pathogen archetypes case studies. (Section 2).

title: Update to
text: Two major updates model made since initial report. : Using data United States America (USA) parameterise aspects model’s representation physical environment (Section 1.1). Including variation propensity infectious disease transmission (call “riskiness”) across individual locations model (Section 1.2).

previous_headings: 1 Major Model Changes > 1.2 Location-Specific Variability in “Riskiness”
what: Modelling Variation in Transmission Riskiness Between Locations of the Same Setting Type
title: Update to
text: Previously, modelled force infection experienced individual \(\) Location \(m\) time \(t\) follows: \[ \lambda_{,j,m}(t) = \frac{\beta_{m} I_{j,m}(t)}{N_{j,m}} \] \(I_m(t)\) number infectious individuals Location \(j\) Setting Type \(m\) time \(t\) , \(N_{j,m}\) total number individuals visiting Location \(j\) Setting Type \(m\) time \(t\) \(\beta_m\) Setting Type-specific (.e. workplace, school, household, leisure-venue specific) transmissibility parameter models average much transmission happens particular Setting Type (e.g. workplaces) compared Settings Types (e.g. schools). total force infection \(\lambda_T\) experienced across Setting Types summed forms basis calculating individual’s probability infection one time-step \(t\): \[ P(infection) = 1 - e^{- \lambda_{,T}t}. \] Previously, \(\beta\) specific Setting Type (.e. different schools, workplaces, households leisure settings) assumed every location setting type e.g. schools \(\beta\). now relaxed assumption. updated force infection term : \[ \lambda_{,j,m}(t) = \frac{\beta_{j,m} I_{j,m}(t)}{N_{j,m}} \] :\[ \beta_{j,m} = \gamma_{j,m}\beta_{m} \] : \[ \gamma_{j,m} \sim Lognormal(\mu_{m}, \sigma_{m}). \] parameter \(\gamma\) controls risky particular Location specific Setting Type relative average Setting Type drawn Lognormal distribution. example, \(\gamma = 1\) setting “risky” average location Setting Type. Meanwhile, \(\gamma = 2\) describe setting twice risky; \(\gamma = 0.5\) describe setting half risky etc. Parameterisation estimation \(\gamma\) described .

what: Step 1: Modelling the Concentration of Infective Virus in an Enclosed Space and Associated Infection Risk
title: Update to
text:
Following approach Blatchley et al, 2024, model concentration pathogen air enclosed space via following ordinary differential equation (ODE): \[ 
u  rac{dC(t)}{dt} =  - QC - k_DC 
u + \pi \] \(v\) space volume, \(C\) infective virus concentration, \(t\) time, \(Q\) flow rate air space, \(k_D\) natural decay constant, \(\) number infectious individuals space, \(\pi\) per capita (infective) virus emission rate. closed-form solution equation : \[ C(t) =   rac{\pi}{\alpha 
u}(1 - e^{-\alpha t}) \] : \[ \alpha =  rac{Q}{
u} + k_D \] \( rac{Q}{
u}\) number air changes per hour. \(\alpha\) therefore number equivalent air changes per hour taking account natural decay virus ventilation-driven removal infective virus. purposes analyses presented , assume volume space following: \[ 
u = N D_mH \]\(N\) number people occupying space, \(D_m\) density people space (.e. number people per m2) \(H\) height space. integrate estimate concentration infective virus space Wells-Riley equation, simple widely used model airbone transmission infectious diseases. Wells-Riley equation takes following form: \[ P_{}(t) =  1 - e^{-r C_{ss}Bt} \] \(P_i\) probability person becomes infected conditional spending time \(t\) space \(C_{ss}\) concentration infective virus, \(B\) volume rate air breathed , \(r\) risk parameter, probability single inhaled infective virus initiate infection.

what: Assessing the impact of far UVC on the burden of endemic respiratory viruses

previous_headings: 2 Assessing the impact of far UVC on the burden of endemic respiratory viruses
title: Update to
text: considered two pathogen archetypes hypothetical virus: “SARS-CoV-2-Like” Archetype - \(R_0\) 2.5, mean latent period 2 days, mean duration infectiousness 4 days, mean duration immunity 365 days. gives approximate infection prevalence 1% (.e. approximately 1 100 individuals infected given timepoint). “Influenza-Like” Archetype - \(R_0\) 1.5, mean latent period 1 day, mean duration infectiousness 2 days, mean duration immunity 365 days. gives approximate infection prevalence 0.3% (.e. 1 330 individuals infected given timepoint). pathogen archetype, investigated effect far UVC efficacy far UVC coverage annual incidence infection, varying: far UVC Coverage: Either 10%, 25% 50% - cases, far UVC assumed installed schools, workplaces leisure locations (.e. households), random set locations within Setting Type. far UVC Efficacy: Either 40%, 60% 80%, assumption far UVC efficacy identical across Settings Locations installed. results analyses presented Figure 2.1. general, estimate far UVC installation larger (proportional) impact disease burden “Influenza-Like” pathogen “SARS-CoV-2-Like” pathogen; increasing far UVC coverage /increasing far UVC efficacy leads increased impact. Assuming 10% coverage 60% efficacy, far UVC installation led 7% (range 2%-11%) reduction annual infection incidence “Influenza-Like” 3% (range 2%-5%) “SARS-CoV-2-Like”. 10% coverage 80% assumed efficacy, 10% (range 6%-16%) 5% (range 2%-8%) respectively. Figure 2.1: impact varying far UVC coverage efficacy annual incidence respiratory virus, “Influenza-Like” “SARS-CoV-2-Like” pathogen archetypes. bars represent mean percentage reduction infection incidence averaged 10 stochastic model simulations run parametrisation, range % reduction incidence across 10 simulations shown error bars.

title: Assessing far UVC interventions with an individual based infectious disease model
text: Individuals exist one four different disease states: Susceptible: susceptible infection pathogen. Exposed: infected currently infectious (often known pathogen’s “incubation period”). Infectious: infectious can infect individuals. Recovered: longer infectious immune future infection. timepoint, individual either susceptible, exposed, infectious, recovered. Individuals infected (S -> E) spending time location infectious individuals. individual calculate location-specific force infection, determines probability infected given timestep. Specifically, force infection experienced individual \(\) Location \(m\) time \(t\) calculated follows: \[ \lambda_{,m}(t) = \frac{\beta_{m} I_m(t)}{N_m} \] \(I_m(t)\) number infectious individuals Location \(m\) time \(t\) , \(N_m\) total number individuals visiting Location \(m\) time \(t\) \(\beta_m\) location specific (.e. workplace, school, household, leisure-venue) transmissibility parameter integrates consideration amount time spent location inherent “riskiness” location (.e. receptive onwards transmission ). Currently within model, Location Type (.e. workplace, school, household, leisure-venue) specific \(\beta\) (.e. \(\beta_{W}\),\(\beta_{S}\) , \(\beta_{H}\), \(\beta_{L}\) respectively) individual locations within Location Type (e.g. schools) \(\beta\) (though changed future versions). total force infection \(\lambda_T\) individual calculated sum household, workplace, school leisure force infections. add additional force infection term \(\lambda_C\) represent types potential infectious contacts represented locations consider (e.g. commute /workplace, grocery shopping etc). represents general mixing among people. total Force Infection experienced individual \(\) therefore calculated : \[ \lambda_{, T} = \lambda_{, H} + \lambda_{, W} + \lambda_{, S} + \lambda_{, L} + \lambda_{, C} \] probability individual \(\) becoming infected one time-step \(t\) calculated summing Location-specific force infections experience calculating following: \[ P(infection) = 1 - \exp(- \lambda_{,T}t). \] Exposed individuals become infectious delay (incubation period). Infectious individuals recover delay (duration infectiousness). recovering, individuals can return susceptible (reflecting loss acquired immunity infection), delay. altering duration acquired immunity infection, framework capacity simulate epidemic (producing single “epidemic wave” dying ) endemic (constantly present population) pathogens (Figure 3.6). title: Assessing far UVC interventions with an individual based infectious disease model
text: Far UVC interventions can installed four location types, combination (.e. either one, two, three, four location types). model efficacy far UVC reduction force infection individual experiences location installed. Specifically, force infection experienced individual \(\) Location \(m\) time \(t\) far UVC installed calculated follows: \[ \lambda_{,m}(t) = (1 - E_{UVC})\frac{\beta_{m} I_m(t)}{N_m} \] \(E_{UVC}\) efficacy far UVC. example, efficacy 50% results reduction force infection individual experiences particular location half. efficacy far UVC within particular Location Type (.e. schools, workplaces, leisure venues) can set individually (.e. produce Location-Type specific efficacy.) Within Location Type, proportion locations covered installation can also specified. Given certain level coverage (e.g. 20%), settings far UVC installed can set according one two coverage strategies: Random: Locations far UVC installed sampled random, random 20% locations type selected. Targeted: Locations far UVC installed chosen order size, largest 20% locations selected receive far UVC. Figure 3.7 provides example illustrating difference two strategies applied schools Location Type. Figure 3.7: Illustration targeted random strategies workplace Location Type.

title: Get started
text: helios R package allows users simulate impact far UVC interventions curtailing spread infectious disease outbreaks. vignette serves demonstrate basic use package. start loading package, well packages used vignette:
code: library(helios) library(individual) library(ggplot2) library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) library(purrr) library(tictoc) theme_set(theme_minimal())

title: Get started
text: Next, define model variables: Aside leisure, entry variables_list CategoricalVariable class: leisure variable RagggedInteger allowing elements different lengths. variables change time (disease_state, leisure, specific_leisure), remain fixed (age_class, workplace, school, household).
code: variables_list <- create_variables(parameters_list) #> There are less than or equal to 2 schools. Consider the population size may be too small! variables_list <- variables_list$variables_list names(variables_list) #> [1] "disease_state"    "age_class"        "workplace"        "school"           #> [5] "household"        "leisure"          "specific_leisure" map(variables_list, class) #> $disease_state #> [1] "CategoricalVariable" "R6"                  #>  #> $age_class #> [1] "CategoricalVariable" "R6"                  #>  #> $workplace #> [1] "CategoricalVariable" "R6"                  #>  #> $school #> [1] "CategoricalVariable" "R6"                  #>  #> $household #> [1] "CategoricalVariable" "R6"                  #>  #> $leisure #> [1] "RaggedInteger" "R6"            #>  #> $specific_leisure #> [1] "CategoricalVariable" "R6"

title: Get started
text: outbreak implemented individual-level SEIR compartmental model. number individuals initially exposed controlled parameters_list$number_initial_E parameters_list$number_initial_I Initially, individuals placed susceptible disease state:
code: (disease_states <- variables_list$disease_state$get_categories()) #> [1] "S" "E" "I" "R" parameters_list$number_initial_E #> [1] 500 parameters_list$number_initial_I #> [1] 400 disease_state_counts <- purrr::map_vec(disease_states, function(x) variables_list$disease_state$get_size_of(values = x))  data.frame("State" = disease_states, "Count" = disease_state_counts) |>   gt::gt()

title: Get started
text: three age classes: children, adults, elderly. age individual remains fixed throughout simulation.
code: parameters_list[c("initial_proportion_child", "initial_proportion_adult", "initial_proportion_elderly")] #> $initial_proportion_child #> [1] 0.2 #>  #> $initial_proportion_adult #> [1] 0.6 #>  #> $initial_proportion_elderly #> [1] 0.2  age_classes <- variables_list$age_class$get_categories() age_class_counts <- purrr::map_vec(age_classes, function(x) variables_list$age_class$get_size_of(values = x))  data.frame(age_classes, age_class_counts) |>   mutate(age_classes = forcats::fct_relevel(age_classes, "child", "adult", "elderly")) |>   ggplot(aes(x = age_classes, y = age_class_counts)) +   geom_col() +   labs(x = "Age class", y = "Count") +   coord_flip()

title: Get started
text: child attends fixed school. Additionally, small number adults attend schools staff:
code: schools <- variables_list$school$get_categories() schools <- schools[schools != "0"] school_sizes <- purrr::map_vec(schools, function(x) variables_list$school$get_size_of(values = x))  data.frame(school_sizes) |>   ggplot(aes(x = school_sizes)) +   geom_histogram() +   labs(x = "School size", y = "Count") #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

title: Get started
text: adult (aside school staff) attends fixed workplace:
code: workplaces <- variables_list$workplace$get_categories() workplaces <- workplaces[workplaces != "0"] workplace_sizes <- purrr::map_vec(workplaces, function(x) variables_list$workplace$get_size_of(values = x))  data.frame(workplace_sizes) |>   ggplot(aes(x = log(workplace_sizes))) +   geom_histogram() +   labs(x = "log(Workplace size)", y = "Count") #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

title: Get started
text: Children, adults elderly people grouped fixed households:  age distribution households follows:
code: households <- variables_list$household$get_categories() household_sizes <- purrr::map_vec(households, function(x) variables_list$household$get_size_of(values = x))  table(household_sizes) |>   data.frame() |>   ggplot(aes(x = household_sizes, y = Freq)) +   geom_col() +   labs(x = "Household size", y = "Count") household_df <- purrr::map_df(households, function(x) {   indices <- variables_list$household$get_index_of(values = x)$to_vector()   if(length(indices > 0)) data.frame("individual" = indices, "household" = as.numeric(x)) })  age_classes <- variables_list$age_class$get_categories() age_df <- purrr::map_df(age_classes, function(x) {   indices <- variables_list$age_class$get_index_of(values = x)$to_vector()   if(length(indices > 0)) data.frame("individual" = indices, "age_class" = x) })  household_df |>   left_join(age_df, by = "individual") |>   group_by(household) |>   summarise(     child = sum(age_class == "child"),     adult = sum(age_class == "adult"),     elderly = sum(age_class == "elderly")   ) |>   group_by(child, adult, elderly) |>   summarise(     count = n()   ) |>   ungroup() |>   arrange(desc(count)) |>   head() |>   gt::gt() #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'child', 'adult'. You can override using #> the `.groups` argument.

title: Get started
text: week, individuals attend leisure venues:
code: leisure_places <- variables_list$leisure$get_values() number_leisure_places <- sapply(leisure_places, function(x) sum(x > 0))  table(number_leisure_places) |>   data.frame() |>   ggplot(aes(x = number_leisure_places, y = Freq)) +   geom_col() +   labs(x = "Number of leisure places attended in a week", y = "Count")

title: Get started
text: Events govern transition individuals disease states: event TargetedEvent class:
code: events_list <- create_events(variables_list = variables_list, parameters_list = parameters_list) names(events_list) #> [1] "EI_event" "IR_event" lapply(events_list, class) #> $EI_event #> [1] "TargetedEvent" "EventBase"     "R6"            #>  #> $IR_event #> [1] "TargetedEvent" "EventBase"     "R6"

title: Get started
text: use fixed number time-steps simulate : object renderer class Render, stores output model timestep:
code: timesteps <- round(parameters_list$simulation_time / parameters_list$dt) renderer <- individual::Render$new(timesteps) class(renderer) #> [1] "Render" "R6"

title: Get started
text: Processes enable queing events:
code: variables_list <- create_variables(parameters_list) #> There are less than or equal to 2 schools. Consider the population size may be too small! parameters_list <- variables_list$parameters_list  variables_list <- variables_list$variables_list events_list <- create_events(variables_list = variables_list, parameters_list = parameters_list) timesteps <- round(parameters_list$simulation_time/parameters_list$dt) renderer <- individual::Render$new(timesteps)  processes_list <- create_processes(   variables_list = variables_list,   events_list = events_list,   parameters_list = parameters_list,   renderer = renderer )  names(processes_list) #> [1] "SE_process" "EI_process" "IR_process" ""

title: Get started
text: See individual::simulation_loop: output simulation contained within renderer, can accessed using to_dataframe() method:
code: individual::simulation_loop(   variables = variables_list,   events = unlist(events_list),   processes = processes_list,   timesteps = timesteps, ) states <- renderer$to_dataframe()  states |>   tidyr::pivot_longer(cols = ends_with("count"), names_to = "compartment", values_to = "value", names_pattern = "(.*)_count") |>   mutate(     compartment = forcats::fct_relevel(compartment, "S", "E", "I", "R")   ) |>   ggplot(aes(x = timestep, y = value, col = compartment)) +   geom_line() +   scale_color_manual(values = c("royalblue3", "firebrick3", "darkorchid3", "orange2")) +   labs(x = "Time-step", y = "Count", col = "Compartment")

title: Technical model description
text: population consists fixed number individuals =1,…,Ni = 1, \ldots, N. individual properties. properties remain constant simulation, others change.

title: Technical model description
text: age categories included model children, adults, elderly. individual fixed age category, assumed change simulation. age category sampled categorical distribution initialisation $$ \mathbb{P}(\text{age}_i = k) = p_k, \\ k \\{\text{child}, \text{adult}, \text{elderly}\}. $$

title: Technical model description
text: Households comprised collections one individuals. consider two approaches.

title: Technical model description
text: parameteric approach, household sizes NjhouseholdN_j^\text{household} drawn Poisson distribution rate parameter λhousehold\lambda^\text{household}Njhousehold∼Poisson(λhousehold). N_j^\text{household} \sim \text{Poisson}(\lambda^\text{household}).  Individuals assigned households. ensure household contains children, one adult paired child assigned household without existing adults.

title: Technical model description
text: bootstrap approach, households age distributions sampled replacement reference data set. reference data baseline_household_demographics derived Office National Statistics 2011 survey used Hinch et al. (2021). bootstrap approach used, age structure overwrite categorical age structure .

title: Technical model description
text: children attend schools. Two approaches number children attending school considered.

title: Technical model description
text: parametric approach, sizes schools drawn log-normal distribution mean μschool\mu^\text{school} variance σschool2{\sigma^\text{school}}^2Njschool∼Lognormal(μschool,σschool2). N^\text{school}_j \sim \text{Lognormal}(\mu^\text{school}, {\sigma^\text{school}}^2).  Schools jj drawn ∑jNjschool≥Nchild\sum_j N^\text{school}_j \geq N^\text{child}. samples Njschool>Nmaxschool∈ℕN^\text{school}_j > N^\text{school}_\text{max}  \\mathbb{N} discarded. final school size adjusted sum school sizes corresponds number children. Assignment children particular schools made using random sampling without replacement.

title: Technical model description
text: bootstrap approach, school sizes sampled replacement reference data set. reference data schools_england obtained 2022/23 census schools England.

title: Technical model description
text: small number adults attend schools staff. school fixed staff student ratio, number staff rounded nearest integer.

title: Technical model description
text: Workplaces attended adults school staff. Following Ferguson et al. (2005), sizes workplaces NjworkplaceN^\text{workplace}_j drawn offset truncated power distribution. cumulative distribution function ℙ(Njworkplace>N)=(1+Nmaxworkplace/a1+m/)c−1(1+Nmaxworkplace/)c−1,N≤Nmaxworkplace, \mathbb{P}(N^\text{workplace}_j > N) = \frac{\left( \frac{1 + N^\text{workplace}_\text{max} / }{1 + m / } \right) ^ c - 1}{(1 + N^\text{workplace}_\text{max} / )^c - 1}, \quad \text{} N \leq N^\text{workplace}_\text{max},  >0,c>0a > 0, c > 0 Nmaxworkplace∈ℕN^\text{workplace}_\text{max} \\mathbb{N}. school sizes, workplace sizes drawn sum exceeds number adults school staff. final workplace adjusted downward. Assignment adults particular workplaces done using random sampling without replacement.

title: Technical model description
text: Leisure venues attended individuals. Leisure venue sizes drawn negative binomial distribution Njleisure∼NB(μleisure,κleisure), N^\text{leisure}_j \sim \text{NB}(\mu^\text{leisure}, \kappa^\text{leisure}),  mean μleisure\mu^\text{leisure} overdispersion parameter κleisure\kappa^\text{leisure}. , samples Njleisure>Nmaxleisure∈ℕN^\text{leisure}_j > N^\text{leisure}_\text{max} \\mathbb{N} discarded final sample adjusted ∑jNjleisure=N\sum_j N^\text{leisure}_j = N. number leisure visits per person per week drawn Poisson distribution, truncated 7 corresponding one leisure visit every day. locations individual’s leisure visits sampled without replacement probability proportional leisure venue size. day week individual visits sampled leisure location also sampled without replacement.

title: Technical model description
text: described implemented!

title: Technical model description
text: consider SEIR compartmental model susceptible, exposed, infectious, recovered disease states. given time, individual exactly one states {S,E,,R}\{S, E, , R\}. Transitions states simulated follows.

title: Technical model description
text: total force infection λ\lambda individual sum household, workplace, school, leisure, community specific force infections λ=λh+λw+λs+λl. \lambda = \lambda_h + \lambda_w + \lambda_s + \lambda_l.  location specific force infection terms given : Household λh\lambda_h: proportional number infectious individuals household multiplied βh\beta_h. Workplace λw\lambda_w: proportional number infectious individuals workplace multiplied βw\beta_w. School λs\lambda_s: proportional number infectious individuals school multiplied βs\beta_s. Leisure λl\lambda_l: proportional number infectious individuals leisure setting multiplied βl\beta_l. Community λc\lambda_c: proportional total number infectious individuals multiplied βc\beta_c. probability infection given time step δ>0\delta > 0 ℙ(S→E)=1−exp(−λδ) \mathbb{P}(S \E) = 1 - \exp(- \lambda \delta)

title: Technical model description
text: Individuals progress exposed infectious random delay d≥1d \geq 1 $$ c \sim \text{Gamma}(2\gamma, 2), \\ d = \text{round}(c + 1). $$ γ>0\gamma > 0 duration exposed set 2. delay dd number time steps δ\delta.

title: Technical model description
text: Individuals progress infectious recovered random disease duration f≥1f \geq 1 $$ e \sim \text{Gamma}(2\upsilon, 2), \\ f = \text{round}(e + 1). $$ υ\upsilon duration infectiousness set 4. disease duration ff number time steps δ\delta.

what: Establish the list of model parameters — get_parameters
title: Establish the list of model parameters — get_parameters
text: function creates named list model parameters used model. example, output get_parameters() provides input functions create_variables() create_events().

title: Establish the list of model parameters — get_parameters
Establish the list of model parameters — get_parameters
text: overrides named list parameters values used instead defaults. parameters : human_population: number humans include model initial_proportion_child: proportion population initially 'child' age class initial_proportion_adult: proportion population initially 'adult' age class initial_proportion_elderly: proportion population initially 'elderly' age class number_initial_S: number humans initially Susceptible (state = S) number_initial_E: number humans initially Exposed (state = E) number_initial_I: number humans initially Infectious (state = ) number_initial_R: number humans initially Recovered (state = R) seed: seed run simulation mean_household_size: TBD workplace_prop_max: maximum size workplace proportion total adult population size workplace_a: parameter Zipf-like distribution workplace size workplace_c: c parameter Zipf-like distribution workplace size school_prop_max: maximum size school proporiton total child population size school_meanlog: meanlog parameter log-normal distribution school size school_sdlog: sdlog parameter log-normal distribution school size school_student_staff_ratio: number students adult staff member leisure_mean_number_settings: TBD leisure_mean_size: TBD leisure_overdispersion_size: TBD leisure_prop_max: TBD duration_exposed: TBD duration_infectious: TBD prob_inf_external: probability susceptible individual infected external source beta_household: TBD beta_workplace: TBD beta_school: TBD beta_leisure: TBD beta_community: TBD dt: TBD simulation_time: TBD household_distribution_country: TBD school_distribution_country: TBD workplace_distribution_country: TBD endemic_or_epidemic: TBD duration_immune: TBD prob_inf_external: TBD Rendering Parameters render_diagnostics: FALSE Far UVC Intervention Parameters: far_uvc_workplace: boolean switch set TRUE far UVC intervention parameterised workplace setting using set_ucv(); default = FALSE far_uvc_workplace_coverage: Proportion coverage far UVC (must numeric value 0 1) far_uvc_workplace_coverage_target: target coverage proportion applies . Select either "individuals" "buildings" far_uvc_workplace_coverage_type: Type coverage. Select "random" random selecting workplaces UVC interventions "targeted" targeting interventions populous workplaces far_uvc_workplace_efficacy: : Efficacy far UVC workplace setting (must numeric value 0 1) far_uvc_workplace_timestep: timestep far UVC implemented workplace setting (must numeric value greater equal 0) far_uvc_school: boolean switch set TRUE far UVC intervention parameterised school setting using set_ucv(); default = FALSE far_uvc_school_coverage: Proportion schools covered far UVC (must numeric value 0 1) far_uvc_school_coverage_target: target coverage proportion applies . Select either "individuals" "buildings" far_uvc_school_coverage_type: Type coverage. Select "random" random selecting schools UVC interventions "targeted" targeting interventions populous schools far_uvc_school_efficacy: : Efficacy far UVC school setting (must numeric value 0 1) far_uvc_school_timestep: timestep far UVC implemented school setting (must numeric value greater equal 0) far_uvc_leisure: boolean switch set TRUE far UVC intervention parameterised leisure setting using set_ucv(); default = FALSE far_uvc_leisure_coverage: Proportion leisure settings covered far UVC (must numeric value 0 1) far_uvc_leisure_coverage_target: target coverage proportion applies . Select either "individuals" "buildings" far_uvc_leisure_coverage_type: Type coverage. Select "random" random selecting leisure settings UVC interventions "targeted" targeting interventions populous leisure settings far_uvc_leisure_efficacy: : Efficacy far UVC leisure setting (must numeric value 0 1) far_uvc_leisure_timestep: timestep far UVC implemented leisure setting (must numeric value greater equal 0) far_uvc_household: boolean switch set TRUE far UVC intervention parameterised household setting using set_ucv(); default = FALSE far_uvc_household_coverage: Proportion households covered far UVC (must numeric value 0 1) far_uvc_household_coverage_target: target coverage proportion applies . Select either "individuals" "buildings" far_uvc_household_coverage_type: Type coverage. Select "random" random selecting households UVC interventions "targeted" targeting interventions populous households far_uvc_household_efficacy: : Efficacy far UVC household setting (must numeric value 0 1) far_uvc_household_timestep: timestep far UVC implemented household setting (must numeric value greater equal 0) Setting-Specific Riskiness Parameters: setting_specific_riskiness_workplace: boolean switch set TRUE setting-specific riskiness parameterised workplace setting using set_setting_specific_riskiness(); default = FALSE setting_specific_riskiness_workplace_meanlog: mean truncated log-normal distribution setting-specific riskiness individual workplaces drawn; default = 0 setting_specific_riskiness_workplace_sdlog: standard deviation truncated log-normal distribution setting-specific riskiness individual workplaces drawn; default = 0.37 setting_specific_riskiness_workplace_min: minimum value truncation left tail truncated log-normal distribution setting-specific riskiness individual workplaces drawn; default = 0.4472 setting_specific_riskiness_workplace_max: maximum value truncation right tail truncated log-normal distribution setting-specific riskiness individual workplaces drawn; default = 2.236 setting_specific_riskiness_school: boolean switch set TRUE setting-specific riskiness parameterised school setting using set_setting_specific_riskiness(); default = FALSE setting_specific_riskiness_school_meanlog: mean truncated log-normal distribution setting-specific riskiness individual schools drawn; default = 0 setting_specific_riskiness_school_sdlog: standard deviation truncated log-normal distribution setting-specific riskiness individual schools drawn; default = 0.37 setting_specific_riskiness_school_min: minimum value truncation left tail truncated log-normal distribution setting-specific riskiness individual schools drawn; default = 0.4472 setting_specific_riskiness_school_max: maximum value truncation right tail truncated log-normal distribution setting-specific riskiness individual schools drawn; default = 2.236 setting_specific_riskiness_leisure: boolean switch set TRUE setting-specific riskiness parameterised leisure setting using set_setting_specific_riskiness(); default = FALSE setting_specific_riskiness_leisure_meanlog: mean truncated log-normal distribution setting-specific riskiness individual leisure locations drawn; default = 0 setting_specific_riskiness_leisure_sdlog: standard deviation truncated log-normal distribution setting-specific riskiness individual leisure settings drawn; what: Update model parameters with far UVC settings — set_uvc
title: Update model parameters with far UVC settings — set_uvc
text: set_uvc() function user-facing function used parameterise far UVC deployment individual setting type (e.g. workplace). function takes arguments helios parameter list, setting type far UVC deployment parameterised, coverage far UVC within location setting type (e.g. coverage individual workplaces within workplace setting class), coverage_type (currently supporting random targeted populated settings), efficacy far UVC setting type, timestep far UVC deployed. function appends additional setting-specific parameters parameter list returns updated version .
